absolute pitch is not so important, and i was not even raised to believe it was particularly possible. then later in life i became disappointed that i didn't prioritize that at an earlier age. i have been able to hijack my strong permanent absolute memory of C to essentially appear to have absolute pitch, at least as good as anyone i've ever met who claims to have it. so that will have to be good enough

what is the difference between a piano and keyboard(instrument)

OR a keyboard can mean any thing with a lot of buttons you can press, could be for typing letters, i'm using one right now, .... the first week i was trying to make one insanely quickly. the second week i was feeling yet again bad and shameful for being unable to execute them at that pace. then for the next 3 weeks or so i was making the song for the video. then, when i began the video, a little tickle in my mind was telling me 'you know that little 3d program i use for occasional little bits of things sometimes, well maybe i should actually just try to start the whole video on there and see what happens.' then i had my mind blown in more different ways and angles than i ever knew existed. 2 months deep into this wild ride, it occured to me that now might actually be the most fine time to go ahead and do what is known as the 'finalcut transition', which long story short means i have to entirely abandon the primary video editing software i have used for the last 5 years. the reason for that is because it was discontinued in 2011. i had been delaying this moment for the past 5 years, because as i always used to say, 'there's never a good time to re-learn everything i know, especially because i've been getting better and better at it every day for the last 5 years.' But, here i was, suddenly doing most of my work in a different program which has the distinct advantage of being available on computers made later than 2014. so being aware of that, a spectacular cascade of events suddenly began to unfold, which i can possibly trace back to viewing a youtube rental of spiderman into the spider verse, for which the only way i could watch it was on a borrowed computer, because my main computer had finally become officially too old to play the movie with ANY browser. that realization, combined with seeing how much faster this borrowed computer was from mine (despite actually being the same age), combined with the outrageousness of the visual effects in that particular movie, combined with the previously mentioned reasons for being ready to make the transition, i decided to reach deep into the savings acount and see if i can make things a little more interesting ............

if you think they are really doing it wrong, you could try to show them what you think is a better way, but if they are not in the mood to hear it then don't worry too much about it. if they hurt themselves a bit later, hopefully they will be more interested in solutions then. but also be careful not to get wrapped up in wishing everyone played like you. it's easy to feel that way. quite often when i see drummers playing matched grip, i tense up and feel uncomfortable watching them. but in reality, it's 2020 and i think 98% of players are matched now. Or to be more specific, i see a surprising amount of players seemingly not doing anything 'moeler'ish whatsoever in their right hi-hat hand. meaning they're not packaging the strokes in groups of 2, in one single motion together. instead they're just hammering away with their entire arm, for every stroke, going through a lot more effort, looking kind of like they're trying to shake a baby or something. But still, it's on you to sell them on whatever better way you have. kind of like, 'hey, looks pretty tiring the way you're trying to pound out every stroke individually, .... well check this out' and then show them. If you sell it well, they will buy it. But it also comes down to whether it's really right for them or not. If it is, they will know, the first time they see it. and if they don't, then it could be time to start seeing other people. i don't really know, i quit teaching after 2 days

Hello Bill. which method do you think is the best way to organize your music? I have lots of music on my archive that i've collected over the course of 20 years and that i deeply care about (i hate all sorts of streaming sites). And i've put a lot of effort into shaping my music directory and now i am looking at it thinking if i can use more simplified method.

My music directory goes like this:
I have a main music directory named 'Music'. And then, this directory divides into the music genres, and then into subgenres, then into artists, then into albums (if there's any). Then you find mp3/flac files in those directories. If a song of said artist doesn't belong to any album (ie. single song, etc) it goes into directory named 'singles' in the artist's directory. Also, any songs whose artists i have only one song of, they go to the another directory named 'Singles' in the proper genre/subgenre.

For example, if i wanna listen t o Michae l Jackson's Billie Jean, the path i have to go thru is Music -> Pop -> Michael Jackson - > Thriller, because i have the entire album. 

Or, 'Zhi-Vago - Celebrate the Love (Club Mix)' is in Music -> Electronic Music -> Trance -> Dream Trance -> Singles, because it's the only song i have of Zhi-Vago.

When you look at it, it really is good method. All songs from all artists in the same genre is in one place. It makes it easier to listen in Winamp. UNLESS artist have many songs from many different music genres. That's the frustrating part.

Do you think this method is good?
no
How did you do yours?

all songs together in list, organized by date added. played in random order, but searchable by name. would be useful to have it sorted accurately by date released, but let's face it, in a world of potentially infinite songs, the info on that is never gonna be complete unless you spend the rest of your life managing that
And your thoughts in general? Thanks.
i try to keep things organized as organically as possible in terms of the song's natural relationship with me. nature is the most powerful organizer

You mention a clue about how you got a 3D model of the earth and highlights of it in a podcast. You have a clue but I just couldn't work out how you did? Could you tell me how you did (If not give another clue)

that's pretty simple actually. just find an equirectangular map of the world (that means it's in the shape of a 2 by 1 rectangle) and then map it onto a sphere. Many programs actually have equirectangular as the default mapping scheme for mapping an image onto a sphere. tutorials out there are plentiful for how to do this in whatever your program of choice may be. in fact, many of those tutorials probably use a globe for the example. Actually, i think many programs actually have a globe all set and ready to go for you, although i didn't find that at the time. i actually ended up swapping out the map mid way through production, for one with a bit more clear CC rights

what's your opinion on wireless ear buds

latency hasn't come down enough for it to be good enough for things requiring instant response to user actions. i.e. music production, or phone conversations, or any type of game where it's important to hear an instant sound response to something you did. they're awesome as long as you're just consuming audio tracks (listening to music, not interacting with it) because once the song starts (half second late) it doesn't matter if the whole song is a half second late. Even video watching is ok, because most video players are smart enough to buffer it right so the vid syncs right with the audio. But if you're recording music, you're still looking at at least a 200ms latency. can't play an instrument that way. And this is not good for intimate phone calls either, because as it is, in the digital world, all cell phone calls have about half second delay (or more) already. And this gets worse when you're doing international, or internet calling. wireless ear phones will add at least quarter second delay on top of that. however, besides all that, it is truly awesome to have no wires. but i'd say the latency probably isn't down enough to discontinue the headphone jack just yet

a very long time ago, i said something along the lines of, "i'm beginning to think that minor thirds are a very important interval. as in, maybe The Most important." and responded something like, "i see what you mean but you may discover that major seconds are more important." and my idea was--look at the minor thirds in a chord to see where it wants to resolve and how badly. Fm6 wants to resolve to C, G7 and G7b9 want to resolve to C, or to Cm, or if you get sneaky they might go to Am or A, or even F# in some cases. and you look at the common notes here: D, F, Ab, B like to go to chords with their root on C, Eb, F#, A. and a lot of things can be explained by this pattern of minor third series.
true

what works best for me is a door touch, kind of a superstition, re-setting my mind from a new listener's point of view, then play the existing song as far as it goes, with metranome, from beginning. then, at the moment when i reach the 'end' (or as far as it goes so far), that's the moment i listen very very carefully. only in that moment, after a clean run through, will i hear the solution. after a window of about 3 to 5 seconds, it gets much much less likely to get a reliable answer. at that point, i can do one of 2 things. i can go ahead and do another door touch and start again, or, if i've done too many run-throughs in a row and burned out the effectiveness of the run-through, i will try to play process of elimination. play detective with it a little. try to at least categorize all imaginable solutions. kind of like on 20 questions where they start by asking 'is it bigger than a breadbox'

With regards to the "Click static text" issue, it might be that the text itself doesn't have a clickable action associated with it. Button components have 2 visible elements to it, the outer bounding box, and the text inside it. In typical usage, a mouse click within the bounding box triggers the action of the button. The click action can be associated with the inclosed text, the bounding box, or both. If the text has no clickable action, it seems reasonable that "missing value" would be returned, even if it is able to find the text itself. Automator may have incorrectly assumed the click action was associated with the text instead of the bounding box, or if your program is particularly nasty, the click action may be just associated with a certain x y position on the screen. Somehow you have to get the name of the actual button box,		 and script a click action on that box rather than the text.

i've looked everywhere in "accessibility inspector", suspecting that it may be hidden neatly behind something. but i don't think you can move anything out of the way in accessibility inspector. but, i've found some pretty thorough scripts that extrapolate every possible UI element (or so they say ....) and gone through every single one of them and not found the secret button i'm looking for. so i don't know

Regarding your AppleScript issue: I've had trouble getting my GUI actions to be recorded by pointing and clicking with a mouse. I DO get the results I want by outlining the keyboard shortcuts for the specific app. Good luck!

actually, the main point of this particular operation is to have solutions for those strange situations where there is absolutely no keyboard shortcut, nor menu item (if it was a menu item i could make a keyboard shortcut for it, but some software likes to go to more advanced planes of inaccessibility)

AppleScript keycodes: https://eastmanreference.com/complete-list-of-applescript-key-codes

Example used with my video editing software:

tell application "System Events"
key code 0 using {command down} # select all
delay 0.5
key code 44 using {shift down, command down} # select top menu
   delay 0.5
   repeat 3 times # arrow left over to Action menu
   key code 123
   end repeat
   delay 1
   repeat 7 times # arrow down to Templates
